tribunal: First-tier Tribunal for Scotland (Housing and Property Chamber)

notice_requirements.notice_period_notes: Generally 84 days (12 weeks). Some grounds have shorter periods. Cannot be served within first 6 months of tenancy.
service_methods: Left in tenant's possession at property
Deposited at property and followed by ordinary post

tribunal_application.form: Form E - Application for an eviction order
tribunal_application.timeframe: Can apply to tribunal once notice period expires. Tribunal usually schedules hearing within 8-12 weeks.
evidence_requirements: Copy of Notice to Leave served on tenant
Proof of service of Notice to Leave
Gas safety certificate (if property has gas)
Electrical Installation Condition Report (EICR) if required
Evidence of right to rent compliance

ground_1.title: Landlord Intends to Sell
ground_1.shortDescription: The landlord intends to sell the let property within 3 months of the termination date specified in the notice.
ground_1.fullText: The landlord intends to sell the let property. The First-tier Tribunal may not make an eviction order on this ground if the Tribunal is not satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_1.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 1
ground_1.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Evidence of intention to sell (estate agent valuation, marketing agreement)
Timeline showing property will be sold within 3 months
Confirmation landlord has not previously used this ground in last 5 years for this property
common_defences: Landlord does not genuinely intend to sell
Property will not be sold within 3 months
Landlord has used this ground before within 5 years
Unreasonable to evict given tenant's circumstances
ground_1.notes: Cannot be used if landlord has already used this ground for the same property in the previous 5 years. Must actually put property on market within 3 months.
ground_1.description: The landlord intends to sell the let property within 3 months of the termination date specified in the notice.

ground_2.title: Property to be Sold by Lender
ground_2.shortDescription: A lender who holds a standard security over the let property intends to sell it.
ground_2.fullText: A lender who holds a standard security over the let property intends to sell it in exercise of a power of sale. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_2.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 2
ground_2.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Lender's notice of intention to sell
common_defences: Lender does not hold valid standard security
Lender does not have power of sale
ground_2.notes: Usually granted when property is being repossessed by mortgage lender.
ground_2.description: A lender who holds a standard security over the let property intends to sell it.

ground_3.title: Landlord Intends to Refurbish
ground_3.shortDescription: The landlord intends to refurbish the let property and cannot reasonably do so while tenant occupies it.
ground_3.fullText: The landlord intends to refurbish the let property and cannot reasonably carry out the refurbishment while the tenant continues to occupy the property. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_3.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 3
ground_3.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Building warrants or planning permissions if required
Evidence tenant must vacate for works to proceed
common_defences: Works not substantial enough to require vacant possession
Works could be done with tenant in occupation
ground_3.notes: Must be substantial refurbishment that genuinely requires vacant possession. Cosmetic works insufficient.
ground_3.description: The landlord intends to refurbish the let property and cannot reasonably do so while tenant occupies it.

ground_4.title: Landlord Intends to Live in Property
ground_4.shortDescription: The landlord intends to occupy the let property as their only or principal home.
ground_4.fullText: The landlord intends to occupy the let property as the landlord's only or principal home. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_4.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 4
ground_4.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Evidence of landlord's intention to live in property
Reasons for needing property as principal home
common_defences: Landlord does not genuinely intend to occupy
Unreasonable to evict given tenant's circumstances
ground_4.notes: Cannot be used if landlord has already used this ground for the same property in previous 5 years.
ground_4.description: The landlord intends to occupy the let property as their only or principal home.

ground_5.title: Family Member Intends to Live in Property
ground_5.shortDescription: A member of the landlord's family intends to occupy the let property as their only or principal home.
ground_5.fullText: A member of the landlord's family intends to occupy the let property as that person's only or principal home. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_5.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 5
ground_5.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Evidence family member intends to occupy
Current living arrangements of family member
common_defences: Family member does not genuinely intend to occupy
ground_5.notes: Family member includes spouse, civil partner, parent, child, sibling, grandparent, grandchild.
ground_5.description: A member of the landlord's family intends to occupy the let property as their only or principal home.

ground_6.title: Change of Use - Non-Residential
ground_6.shortDescription: The landlord intends to use the let property for a non-residential purpose.
ground_6.fullText: The landlord intends to use the let property for a purpose other than providing a home. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_6.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 6
ground_6.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Planning permission or change-of-use application (if required)
common_defences: No genuine intention to change use
Change of use could occur with tenant in occupation
Unreasonable to evict given tenant's circumstances
ground_6.notes: 84-day notice period. Requires credible plan to take property out of residential use.
ground_6.description: The landlord intends to use the let property for a non-residential purpose.

ground_7.title: Religious Worker Accommodation
ground_7.shortDescription: The property is required for use by a religious worker.
ground_7.fullText: The let property is held for use for the purpose of a minister or full-time lay missionary of a religious denomination, and is required for that purpose. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_7.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 7
ground_7.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Evidence property is held for religious worker use
Statement of need from the religious body
Timeline showing when the property is required
common_defences: Property not genuinely required for religious worker
Unreasonable to evict given tenant's circumstances
ground_7.notes: 84-day notice period. Must show genuine requirement for a minister or missionary.
ground_7.description: The property is required for use by a religious worker.

ground_8.title: No Longer Employee
ground_8.shortDescription: Tenant is no longer an employee of the landlord and the tenancy was linked to employment.
ground_8.fullText: The tenant is no longer, or never became, an employee of the landlord and the tenancy was granted in connection with that employment. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_8.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 1, Ground 8
ground_8.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Employment contract linking housing to employment
Proof employment has ended or was not taken up
common_defences: Housing not genuinely tied to employment
ground_8.notes: 84-day notice period. Often used for tied accommodation when employment ends.
ground_8.description: Tenant is no longer an employee of the landlord and the tenancy was linked to employment.

ground_9.title: No Longer Requires Supported Accommodation
ground_9.shortDescription: The tenant no longer needs the supported accommodation provided at the let property.
ground_9.fullText: The tenant has been provided with supported accommodation and no longer requires that support. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_9.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 2, Ground 9
ground_9.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Assessment showing support is no longer required
ground_9.notes: 28-day notice period. Often used by supported accommodation providers when support ends.
ground_9.description: The tenant no longer needs the supported accommodation provided at the let property.

ground_10.title: Breach of Tenancy
ground_10.shortDescription: The tenant has breached a term of the tenancy (other than rent payment).
ground_10.fullText: The tenant has breached a term of the tenancy agreement. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_10.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 2, Ground 10
ground_10.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Photographs or witness statements if applicable
common_defences: Breach not serious enough to warrant eviction
ground_10.notes: Shorter 28-day notice period. Breach must be material. Minor breaches unlikely to succeed.
ground_10.description: The tenant has breached a term of the tenancy (other than rent payment).

ground_11.title: Tenant Not Occupying Let Property
ground_11.shortDescription: The tenant is no longer occupying the let property as their home.
ground_11.fullText: The tenant is not occupying the let property as the tenant's home. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_11.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 3, Ground 11
ground_11.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Inspection records showing property not occupied
common_defences: Tenant is occupying or has valid reason for temporary absence
ground_11.notes: 28-day notice period. Often relies on circumstantial evidence of vacancy.
ground_11.description: The tenant is no longer occupying the let property as their home.

ground_12.title: Tenant Convicted of Certain Offences
ground_12.shortDescription: The tenant has been convicted of using the let property, or allowing it to be used, for immoral or illegal purposes.
ground_12.fullText: The tenant has been convicted of using the let property, or allowing it to be used, for immoral or illegal purposes, or of an offence punishable by imprisonment committed in or in the locality of the let property. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_12.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 3, Ground 12
ground_12.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Evidence offence related to property or locality
common_defences: Conviction not related to property or locality
ground_12.notes: 28-day notice period. Must be actual criminal conviction.
ground_12.description: The tenant has been convicted of using the let property, or allowing it to be used, for immoral or illegal purposes.

ground_13.title: Antisocial Behaviour
ground_13.shortDescription: The tenant has engaged in antisocial behaviour.
ground_13.fullText: The tenant has engaged in relevant antisocial behaviour. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_13.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 3, Ground 13
ground_13.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Police reports and crime reference numbers
ground_13.notes: 28-day notice period. 'Relevant antisocial behaviour' includes causing alarm, distress, nuisance, or annoyance.
ground_13.description: The tenant has engaged in antisocial behaviour.

ground_14.title: Association with Antisocial Person
ground_14.shortDescription: The tenant associates in the let property with a person who has engaged in antisocial behaviour.
ground_14.fullText: The tenant associates in the let property with a person who has engaged in relevant antisocial behaviour. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_14.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 3, Ground 14
ground_14.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Proof tenant associates with this person at property
common_defences: Associated person has not engaged in antisocial behaviour
ground_14.notes: 28-day notice period. Must show both association and antisocial behaviour.
ground_14.description: The tenant associates in the let property with a person who has engaged in antisocial behaviour.

ground_15.title: Landlord Registration / Fit and Proper
ground_15.shortDescription: The landlord is not registered or has ceased to be registered.
ground_15.fullText: The landlord is not, or has ceased to be, registered by the local council or is no longer regarded as fit and proper. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_15.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 4, Ground 15
ground_15.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Local authority notice of refusal or removal from landlord register
Correspondence confirming landlord not fit and proper
common_defences: Unreasonable to evict given tenant's circumstances
ground_15.notes: 28-day notice period. Tied to landlord registration compliance.
ground_15.description: The landlord is not registered or has ceased to be registered.

ground_16.title: HMO Licence Revoked or Refused
ground_16.shortDescription: The HMO licence for the property has been revoked or an application has been refused.
ground_16.fullText: The HMO licence relating to the let property has been revoked by the local council or an application for an HMO licence has been refused. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_16.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 4, Ground 16
ground_16.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Local authority notice revoking or refusing HMO licence
common_defences: Unreasonable to evict while compliance steps underway
ground_16.notes: 28-day notice period. Applies where HMO licence cannot be lawfully maintained.
ground_16.description: The HMO licence for the property has been revoked or an application has been refused.

ground_17.title: Overcrowding Statutory Notice
ground_17.shortDescription: An overcrowding statutory notice has been served on the landlord or tenant.
ground_17.fullText: An overcrowding statutory notice has been served in respect of the let property. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts.
ground_17.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 4, Ground 17
ground_17.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
ground_17.notes: 28-day notice period. Used to address statutory overcrowding notices.
ground_17.description: An overcrowding statutory notice has been served on the landlord or tenant.

ground_18.title: Rent Arrears - 3 Consecutive Months
ground_18.shortDescription: The tenant has been in rent arrears for 3 or more consecutive months.
ground_18.fullText: The tenant has been in rent arrears for 3 or more consecutive months. The Tribunal may make an eviction order on this ground only if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to issue an eviction order on account of those facts, and that the tenant has been in arrears of rent for a continuous period of 3 or more months.
ground_18.statute: Private Housing (Tenancies) (Scotland) Act 2016, Schedule 3, Part 4, Ground 18
ground_18.tribunal_decision: Discretionary - tribunal must be satisfied it is reasonable to evict
required_evidence: Rent account showing 3+ months continuous arrears
Proof of rent amount and payment schedule
Evidence of attempts to recover arrears
Details of any payment plan attempts
common_defences: Tenant made reasonable efforts to pay
ground_18.notes: 28-day notice period. Must be continuous arrears for 3 months. Tribunal will consider tenant's circumstances and whether eviction is reasonable.
ground_18.description: The tenant has been in rent arrears for 3 or more consecutive months.

deposit_protection.notes: Must protect deposit in approved scheme and provide prescribed information

gas_safety.notes: Must provide copy to tenant within 28 days of issue

exemptions: Buildings in conservation areas (with local authority consent)
epc.notes: Must be provided before marketing property

eicr.renewal: Every 5 years or on change of tenancy
eicr.notes: Electrical Installation Condition Report required for all private tenancies

repairing_standard.description: Property must meet the repairing standard under Housing (Scotland) Act 2006
key_requirements: Structure and exterior in reasonable repair
Installations for water, gas, electricity in reasonable repair
Heating and hot water in reasonable repair
Secure and safe from forced entry
Supplied with smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors

landlord_registration.notes: All private landlords in Scotland must register with local council

hmo_licensing.required_if: 3 or more unrelated tenants sharing facilities
hmo_licensing.notes: HMO license required before letting. Requirements vary by council.
